title: Quiz 3: August 2015 Licensure Exam
description: Complete licensure examination covering Management, Education, Mental Health, and Community Health from August 2015. Contains all MCQs, Short Answer, and Essay concepts.

questions.question: Organizational structure primarily refers to:

options.text: How activities are coordinated and controlled
The location of departments and offices
The policy statement developed by the organization

questions.explanation: Organizational structure defines how tasks are formally divided, grouped, and coordinated. It determines the hierarchy, reporting relationships, and communication channels.
questions.hint: Think about the framework of the organization.

questions.question: Together, authority and responsibility are:
questions.explanation: Authority and responsibility must go hand in hand (parity). They complement each other; having authority without responsibility is dangerous, and responsibility without authority is ineffective.
questions.hint: They complete each other like two sides of a coin.

questions.question: The first step in the decision-making process is:
questions.explanation: You cannot make a decision unless you know what the issue is. The process starts with identifying/defining the problem.
questions.hint: What is the very first thing you need to know to solve something?

questions.question: Which of the following is a characteristic of planned change?

options.text: It always works towards the betterment of employees

questions.explanation: Planned change is a purposeful, calculated, and proactive effort to improve a system, as opposed to accidental or reactive change.
questions.hint: It doesn't just happen by accident.

questions.question: Situational leadership theory:

options.text: Embodies the idea that the leader directs goal-oriented behaviour
Explains leadership through taking into account forces in the situation, leader and followers
Presents supportive evidence collected in organizations
Suggests that a great leader will arise when controlled with appropriate situation

questions.explanation: Situational leadership theories propose that effective leadership depends on the interaction between the leader, the followers, and the specific situation (context).
questions.hint: It depends on the context.

questions.question: Which method is appropriate for teaching the acquisition of psychomotor skills?
questions.explanation: Psychomotor skills involve physical movement. Demonstration (showing how) followed by practice is the standard method for teaching these skills.
questions.hint: Monkey see, monkey do.

questions.question: Negative reinforcement involves:

options.text: An attempt to decrease the likelihood of behaviour
Giving a reward to strengthen a response
Removal of an unfavorable event to strengthen a response

questions.explanation: Negative reinforcement strengthens a behavior by removing an aversive (unpleasant) stimulus. It is 'negative' because something is subtracted/removed.
questions.hint: Taking away something bad to encourage good behavior.

questions.question: Summative assessment:

options.text: Allows for fine tuning of instruction

questions.explanation: Summative assessment evaluates student learning at the end of an instructional unit by comparing it against a standard (monitoring the final outcome).
questions.hint: Think 'Summary' or 'Sum total' at the end.

questions.question: Educational objectives have been divided into how many domains?
questions.explanation: Bloom's Taxonomy divides objectives into three domains: Cognitive (Knowledge), Affective (Attitude), and Psychomotor (Skills).
questions.hint: Head, Heart, and Hands.

questions.question: The document that stipulates the details of content to be taught is:
questions.explanation: A syllabus is the specific list of topics and content to be covered in a course. The curriculum is broader; the lesson plan is for a single session.
questions.hint: You usually get this at the start of a specific class.

questions.question: Which is the primary source of data for the client's database?
questions.explanation: The client is always the primary source. All other sources are secondary.
questions.hint: Who knows the patient best?

questions.question: What is the most widely accepted reason for nurses using the nursing process?

options.text: Standardise the care of clients with the same diagnoses

questions.explanation: The nursing process provides a systematic method that standardizes practice, ensuring consistency and quality of care.
questions.hint: It creates a standard approach.

questions.question: The singleness of purpose that makes possible the creation of one plan of action to guide managers is:
questions.explanation: Unity of Direction: one head and one plan for a group of activities having the same objective.
questions.hint: One plan, one direction.

questions.question: A reporting relationship where an employee receives orders from only one supervisor is known as:
questions.explanation: Unity of Command: An employee should report to no more than one manager to avoid conflicting instructions.
questions.hint: One boss.

questions.question: Fayol's theory of equity specifies that:

options.text: Employees should be paid equally regardless of positions
Employees should be treated with respect and justice
People should get equal pay for equal work

questions.explanation: Equity in management implies kindness and justice in dealing with employees to elicit loyalty.
questions.hint: It's about fairness and respect.

questions.question: Crime is always related to psychopathology.
questions.explanation: False. Most crimes are committed by individuals without any diagnosable psychopathology. Socio-economic factors often play a larger role.
questions.hint: Do all criminals have a mental illness?

questions.question: Mentally ill patients can be used in research.
questions.explanation: True. They can participate if ethical guidelines (informed consent, protection of vulnerable populations) are strictly followed.
questions.hint: Vulnerable populations can participate with protections.

questions.question: Match the personality disorder with its description:

pairs.right: Colourful, dramatic and extroverted behaviour, very emotional
Pervasive and excessive need to be cared for

questions.explanation: Histrionic=Dramatic; Dependent=Needy; Borderline=Unstable; Antisocial=No guilt.
questions.hint: Match the key behavioral traits.

questions.question: Rattling of leaves interpreted as a reproaching voice is an example of:
questions.explanation: An illusion is a misinterpretation of a REAL external stimulus (the leaves). A hallucination has no external stimulus.
questions.hint: There is a real sound, but it is misinterpreted.

questions.question: A common manageable side effect of neuroleptics is:
questions.explanation: Tremors (pseudo-parkinsonism) are common Extrapyramidal Side Effects (EPS) of antipsychotics.
questions.hint: Think of Parkinson-like symptoms.

questions.question: Differentiate between the following terms:
questions.explanation: Obsession=Think, Compulsion=Act. IV=Cause, DV=Effect. Leadership=People, Management=Tasks.
questions.hint: Match the pairs.

questions.question: Select the functions of the Kenya Board of Mental Health:

options.text: Advise government on mental health matters
Approve establishment of mental health units

questions.explanation: The Board is a regulatory and advisory body, not a direct clinical provider.
questions.hint: Think regulation and advice, not direct treatment.

questions.question: Which of the following are types of nursing care delivery systems?
questions.explanation: Standard delivery systems include Functional, Team, Primary, and Case Management.
questions.hint: How is work organized on a ward?

questions.question: Identify the roles of a nurse manager:
questions.explanation: POSDC: Planning, Organizing, Staffing, Directing, Controlling.
questions.hint: Classic management functions.

questions.question: Match the Malaria endemicity classification with its description:

pairs.right: Intense year-round transmission; >75% spleen rate in children
Low transmission; <10% spleen rate; epidemic prone

questions.explanation: Classification is based on spleen rates in children: Holo (>75%), Hyper (50-75%), Meso (11-50%), Hypo (<10%).
questions.hint: Holo is whole/all; Hypo is low.

questions.question: Select the clinical pictures of severe, complicated malaria:
questions.explanation: Severe malaria affects major organs: Brain (Cerebral), Blood (Anemia), Kidneys (Renal), Lungs (Edema), and Metabolism (Hypoglycemia).
questions.hint: Think organ failure and life-threatening signs.

questions.question: What are the objectives of a School Health Program?
questions.explanation: Objectives focus on promotion, prevention, screening, environment, and education within the school setting.
questions.hint: Keeping kids healthy at school.

questions.question: Arrange the steps for organizing a School Health Service using the nursing process:
questions.explanation: ADPIE applies here too: Assess, Diagnose, Plan, Implement, Evaluate.
questions.hint: The standard nursing process.
